# 157\n
{Wells Cathedral Library, Liber Albus I, language 2, fols. 17v-18r}\n
C13a2 (ca 1240)\n
355 146 E\n
{=Wells, Somerset=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this language, which is\n
only slightly modified from Old English. The same hand records four\n
documents on fol. 14r in a somewhat later kind of language=}\n
{=Script - Proto-gothic book hand influenced by contemporary document hand=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{~f17v~}\n
{=The first third of the folio is in Latin=}\n
{\\}\n

{=There follows the Latin version of the above writ=}\n

\n
# 173\n
{Worcester Cathedral, Chapter Library F 174, fols. 1r-63r: AElfric\'s Grammar and Glossary}\n
C13a\n
384 254 E\n
{=Worcester, Worcs=}\n
{=Sample represents all the legible bits of English in this text only\n
in the same hand (the Worcester Tremulous Hand), as the Worcester\n
Fragments (text no. 172 worcthfragst.tag) and the Nicene Creed (text no.\n
171 worcthcreedt.tag) which have been tagged separately because the\n
language is slightly different, that of the Grammar and Glossary being\n
influenced by being copied from an Old English original=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata. The hand has a characteristic leftward\n
slant, is variable in size, regularity and in degree of tremor=}\n
{=Status - complex commentary, adding of Latin text for context and\n
punctuation done up to the end of f28v so far=}\n
{=The manuscript is composed of sheets of different sizes most of\n
which are incomplete having been cut up in C15 and pasted together\n
for use as bindings. The manuscript was reconstituted in C19 but\n
fol. 10 belongs between fols. 1 and 2. For this tagged text I have\n
placed it as fol. 2 in the correct order for the text and renumbered all\n
subsequent folios accordingly. All the fol. references in the tagged\n
text apart from fols. 1 and 2 will have a number one more than their\n
actual place in the manuscript. As a result of its history, the\n
manuscript is in poor condition with the edges cropped and\n
considerable text lost also as a result of the paste used on it\n
and the subsequent washing off of the paste. Since I have worked\n
with a microfilm it is likely that the problems of legibility are\n
worse than they would have been using the original. I have only\n
tagged complete or almost complete words. Original presence of what\n
is now illegible or missing text is noted within braces and square\n
brackets according to usual practice. Supplied words are not\n
reconstructions but are modern English equivalents of the conjectured\n
text given to aid comprehension. The same applies to such of the\n
Latin text I have been able to decipher. I have tried to put in\n
as much of the Latin as possible because it is necessary for the\n
understanding of the context of much of the English=}\n
{~f1r~}\n
{=Begins imperfectly - the preface and the first few lines of the\n
grammar itself are lost. This first folio is also much rubbed with\n
inevitable loss of legibility=}\n
{[sound is struck air perceptible to hearing[}\n

{=Note that the superscript I implies, as usual, a missing R which would,\n

{=This leaf is badly defective, the outer half having been cut away. The\n
half, near the binding, is itself in two halves although no text\n
has been lost between the top and the bottom half. The result, however\n
is that text is missing from the right side of the recto and from the\n
left side of the verso of this leaf. I have supplied the Latin inside\n
brackets but in lower case and without abbreviations and the missing English\n
text is given in modern English equivalent in the usual way=}\n

{[are always lengthened .[}\n
{([et pluraliter legimus] \\ LEGITIS . LEGUnT . *EODEm Mod^O TEmPoRe .\n
PreTeriTo [inperfecto legebam . -egebas . - egebat . & pluraliter] \\\n
-GEBAMUR . -GEBATIS . -GEBAnT . *EOD[em modo tempore preterito perfecto\n
legi .-gisti .] \\ -GIT &2 PLuraliteR LEGIMUS . -GISTIS . -GERUnT [vel\n
legere . Eodem modo tempore preterito plusquam] \\ PerFECTO . LEGERAm .\n
-GERAS . -GERAT . & PLuraliteR [legeramus . -geratis . -gerant . Eodem]\n
\\ Mod^O TEmPoRe FUTURO LEGAm . -GES . -GET . & P[luraliter legemus .\n
-getis . -gent . Inperatiuo modo tempore pre]\\SENTI AD SeCunDAM &\n
TERCIAm PerSONAm . [lege . legat & pluarliter legamus . -gite .] \\ -GAnT\n
. EODEm Mod^O TemPoRe FUTurO . LEGITO [tu . legito ille . & pluraliter .\n
legamus . legi]TOTE . LEGUNTO vel LEGUNTOTE . *O[ptatiuo modo tempore\n
presenti & preterito inperfecti] \\ UTinam LEGEREm . LEGERES . -GERET . &\n
PLuraliteR [utinam legeremus . legeretis . legerunt . Eodem] \\ Mod^O\n
TEmPoRe PreTeriTO PerFECTO & PLUSQUAm [perfecto utinam . legissem .\n
legisses . legisset . &] \\ PLuraliteR . UTinam -GISSEMUS . -GISSETIS .\n
-GIS[sent . Eodem modo temore futuro . utinam legam . legas . legat .]    \n
{\\}\n
{~f33v~}\n
{([& pluraliter utinam legamus . legatis .] LEGAnT . *CONIUNCTiuO Mod^O\n
TEmPoRe \\ [presenti cum legam . cum legas . cum legat . & pluralite]R\n
CUM LEGAMus . -GATIS . -GANT . \\ [Eodem modo tempore preterito\n
inperfecto . cum lege]REm . -GERES . -GERET . & PLuraliteR CUm\n
LE\\[geremus . cum legeretis . cum legerent . Eodem modo t]EmPoRe\n

\n
# 172\n
{Worcester Cathedral, Chapter Library F 174, fols. 63r-66v: Worcester Fragments}\n
C13a\n
384 254 N\n
{=Worcester, Worcs=}\n
{=Sample consists of this text only, in the same hand (the Worcester\n
Tremulous Hand), as his version of Aelfric\'s Grammar and Glossary (see\n
text no. 173 worcthgrglt.tag) and the Nicene Creed (text no. 171\n
worcthcreedt.tag) which have been tagged separately because the language\n
is slightly different, that of the Grammar and Glossary being influenced\n
by being copied from an Old English original=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata. The hand has a characteristic leftward\n
slant, is variable in size, regularity and in degree of tremor=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The manuscript is composed of sheets of different sizes most of which\n
are incomplete having been cut up in C15 and pasted together for use as\n
bindings. The manuscript was reconstituted in C19 but is in poor condition\n
with the edges cropped and considerable text lost also as a result of the\n
paste used on it and the subsequent washing off of the paste. Since I have\n
worked with a microfilm rather than the original manuscript it is likely\n
that the problems of legibility are worse than they would have been using\n
the original. I have only tagged complete or almost complete words. The\n
manuscript has been cropped at the top leading to loss of text at the\n
beginning of each side of each folio. The resulting fragments are here\n
treated as separate texts. The first is part of a poem on the disuse of\n
English. The following seven are all fragments of the same poem, a version\n
of the Soul\'s Address to the Body. The MS has also been cropped on the\n
outer edge with the loss of probably 3 or 4 letters at the end of each\n
line of the rectos and beginning of each line of the versos. The corner\n
near the bound edge is also damaged with some loss to the last lines of\n
each side. The words supplied in square brackets in lower case are to\n
aid comprehension and do not attempt to supply MS readings. They are derived\n
from a consensus of suggested readings that have been supplied by other editors=}\n
{~f63r~}\n
{([]anCtuS(}\n
\'_BEDA\n

{[his[}\n
$deathevil/n<pr_[D]Ey-OFULE $evil/n<pr-k_-OFULE\n
{=This seems the only possible reading. F is this scribe\'s usual usage\n
(as in Old English) for intervocalic [v] as well as for initial and\n
final [f]. The only other instance of the word "evil" in this text\n
is spelled UFEL. O for [u] is not common in this scribe\'s usage but\n
cf. BIVONDEN past participle of "bewind" and the correction of\n
original BOTEN to BUTEN above. U for unstressed vowel is unparalleled\n
in this text language (in spite of its SWML origins), but may\n
represent [v], reinforcing F, cf WOLFUES "wolves" in laud108at.tag=} \n
{.}\n

{154}\n
{London, BL Cotton Cleopatra C vi, hand D: additions and corrections}\n
{=I have not attempted to transcribe bits of words added or substituted\n
by Scribe D, only whole words and longer stretches of text. These are\n
given the grammatical tags suitable to their position in the\n
surrounding text, which may be found in Dobson (1972). Although the\n
text here is thus discontinuous, line breaks and folio references are\n
indicated in the usual way. Braces with no back slash indicate textual\n
discontinuity but no line break=}\n

# 118\n
{BL Cotton Titus D xviii, fols. 14r-105r: Ancrene Riwle}\n
C13a2(1240-50)\n
370 349 E\n
{=S Cheshire=}\n
{=Sample tagged - fols. 14r-40r. The texts in this MS are all in one\n
hand but in different types of language. Ancrene Riwle is in two basic\n
types: T1, a homogeneous North-West Midland type of language,\n
represented by this sample; and T2, a mixture of T1 and something more\n
southerly, for which see text no. 119. Apart from the stretches\n
noticed as T2 all the rest of AR is in T1. The other texts (each\n
tagged separately) are in mixed language similar to T2, apart from the\n
Wohunge of ure Lauerd for which see text no. 122 (tituswoht.tag)=}\n
{=Script - Textura semi-quadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Begins imperfectly=}\n
{~f14ra~}\n
$such/ajpl_SwUCH+E $/plaj_+E\n
$other/ajpl_OdR+E $/plaj_+E\n
$thing/npl_yING+ES $/pln_+ES\n
$as/av_AS\n

{=SwA followed by what is probably intended as a medieval question mark\n

$custel/nOd_CUSTEL\n
{=Meaning is clear from the context - something heavy to tether or\n
hobble the cow. But the word is otherwise unknown. The other texts have\n
CUBBEL which is also rare and whose etymology is also not entirely clear\n
though it might have ON cognates. If this is an error for CUBBEL it is\n
hard to see how the mistake could have come about palaeographcially so\n
it may be local usage=}\n

$/T<pr_yE\n
